pageContext.description:
The St Olav altarpiece was conceived as a diptych and originally painted for the Chapel of the Bergenfahrer in St Marien. The whole complex consisted of three painted panels and a carved shrine. When closed the panel depicting the three female saints Barbara, Catherine and Dorothy was visible. It then opened out like a book to really the other two panels showing St Olav with the two evangelists John and Matthew on the left and the deposition on the right-hand side.  When opened a second time a sculptural ensemble was revealed, depicting the Holy Kinship on one side and the Sts Roche, Anthony and Sebastian on the other. These saints were flanked either side by diminutive figures of the apostles in vertical niches. 
This panel shows Christ at the centre of the composition, being taken down from the cross by Joseph of Arimathia and Nicodemus as described in St John’s Gospel. At the left are the three Marys and St John while Mary Magdalene kneels at the right of the cross and the Virgin, beyond grief, observes from behind. The figurative group is set against a gilded background with a punched decorative pattern.
[cda 2021]

metadata.title: St Olav Altarpiece: The Deposition [inner side, left wing]

pageContext.provenance:
- the contract for the altarpiece was drawn up and signed on the 09.10.1522 and the completed work was delivered and installed in the Bergenfahrerkapelle, in St. Marien, Lübeck in March 1524 (c. one year later than originally agreed upon).
[Bruns 1900, CXXXI]
- the altarpiece was destroyed during the 2nd World War
[Emmendörffer 1997, 42]

tests.text:
- the frame member were each c. 9-10 cm in width; flat with a moulded profile on each side; it was gilded and the flat section was decorated with painted patterns; in this case rhombi with jagged edged quatrefoils.

[Emmendörffer 1997, 75]

titles.title: St Olav Altarpiece: The Deposition [inner side, left wing]
